newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU ministers in dock over beef label decision.
newsitem.headline: EU ministers in dock over beef label decision.

text.p: The European Commission has decided to take the European Union's Council of Ministers to court because it refused to give the European Parliament a role in deciding on beef labelling, a spokesman said on Wednesday.
"The Commission discussed this last night and has decided to take the Council to the Court of Justice," spokesman Joao Vale de Almeida told a news conference.
The Commission will hold talks with the parliament to see whether joint action before the Luxembourg court would be appropriate, he added.
Last week the parliament said they were considering taking the council to court and were seeking an opinion from their legal affairs committee.

The dispute arises out of last week's unanimous decision by farm ministers to reject a revised Commission proposal on beef labelling and identification and registration of cattle under a procedure allowing the parliament full co-decision.
Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler put forward the new proposal under article 100a of the Treaty of Rome which requires the parliament to agree with the council.
But ministers rejected the move and adopted a proposal which was already before them under article 43 which requires only that the parliament should give an opinion.

The Commission had promised to give the EU's directly elected assembly a full role after the parliament issued a damning report on the way the Commission and the EU had handled the health scare caused by BSE (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy).

Last week's decision by ministers provides for a mandatory sustem of labelling for all beef and beef products, including country of origin, as well as rules on identification and registration of all cattle.
Announcing the decision to refer the case to court, Almeida told the news conference: "The Commission decided to change the centre of gravity to give greater emphasis to consumer and public health."
He said that the decision was political but with "strong legal arguments". -- Brussels Newsroom 32 2 287 6800
